entities.name: BLACK HOLES
entities.description: Black holes are cosmic entities characterized by their immense gravitational pull, which is so strong that not even light can escape. They are formed from the remnants of massive stars that have undergone a supernova explosion and collapsed under their own gravity. Black holes have a singularity at their center and an event horizon, and they play a crucial role in the study of physics, including general relativity and quantum mechanics.

entities.name: SCIENTISTS
entities.description: Scientists are individuals who study and research various aspects of black holes, including their formation, properties, and the implications for physics and cosmology.

entities.name: SUPERNOVA EXPLOSION
entities.description: A supernova explosion is a powerful and luminous stellar explosion that marks the end of a massive star's life cycle, leading to the formation of a black hole.

entities.name: SINGULARITY
entities.description: A singularity is a point of infinite density and zero volume at the center of a black hole, where the laws of physics as we know them break down.

entities.name: EVENT HORIZON
entities.description: The event horizon is the boundary around a black hole beyond which nothing can escape the gravitational pull, not even light.

entities.name: GRAVITATIONAL TIME DILATION
entities.description: Gravitational time dilation is a phenomenon where time slows down near a black hole due to the strong gravitational field, relative to observers further away.

entities.name: SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS
entities.description: The Schwarzschild radius is the radius at which the escape velocity equals the speed of light, defining the boundary of a black hole's event horizon.

entities.name: HOLOGRAPHIC PRINCIPLE
entities.description: The holographic principle is a concept in theoretical physics suggesting that all the information about the contents of a black hole is encoded on its event horizon, challenging traditional views on information storage in the universe.

entities.name: INFORMATION PARADOX
entities.description: The information paradox is a theoretical problem in physics concerning the fate of information that falls into a black hole and whether it is lost forever, leading to questions about the conservation of information.

entities.name: GENERAL RELATIVITY
entities.description: General relativity is a theory of gravitation developed by Albert Einstein, which describes gravity as the curvature of spacetime caused by mass and energy.

entities.name: QUANTUM MECHANICS
entities.description: Quantum mechanics is a fundamental theory in physics that describes the physical properties of nature at the scale of atoms and subatomic particles, and it plays a crucial role in understanding black holes and their properties.

entities.name: STRING THEORY
entities.description: String theory is a theoretical framework in physics that attempts to reconcile general relativity and quantum mechanics by describing the fundamental constituents of the universe as one-dimensional "strings."

entities.name: LIGO OBSERVATORY
entities.description: The LIGO (Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory) is a facility that detected gravitational waves resulting from the merger of two black holes, providing evidence for the existence of black holes and opening new avenues for their study.

entities.name: STEPHEN HAWKING
entities.description: Stephen Hawking was a renowned theoretical physicist who made significant contributions to the study of black holes, including the prediction of Hawking radiation, which suggests that black holes emit a faint glow of radiation due to quantum effects near the event horizon.

entities.name: HAWKING RADIATION
entities.description: Hawking radiation is a theoretical prediction that black holes emit a faint glow of radiation due to quantum effects near the event horizon, causing black holes to slowly lose mass and eventually evaporate over time.

entities.name: GRAVITATIONAL WAVES
entities.description: Gravitational waves are ripples in spacetime caused by the acceleration of massive objects, such as the merger of two black holes, and were first detected by the LIGO observatory.

entities.name: QUANTUM GRAVITY
entities.description: Quantum gravity is a theoretical framework that attempts to reconcile general relativity and quantum mechanics, particularly in the context of the singularity at the center of a black hole.
